Without taking this class, I would not have realized that the social norms we have gotten used to affect the disadvantaged groups negatively in unbelievable ways. I am now aware of the need of change in our society thanks to this course.

This course provided me with a systematic and scientific understanding to support my inherent incline towards fighting against systems of oppression.
I thoroughly learned the concepts of the sociological canon and, most important of all, more than what is seen to be important by western sociologists. I left Yale with an informed opinion, with a strong stance against voices opposing my ideals and with a deeply rooted passion to delve deeper into the workings of Marx and modern-day sociologists, who are pushing forward in questions of oppression and exploitation.

I find the course broadening my mind, because of different points of view on society that I have read about. It was also interesting to hear about perception of the issues of people with different cultural background. Although I was a bit afraid about participating in discussions, the teacher and group was really friendly so I could try it sometimes.
I think the course was challenging and developing also to my language skills, especially because of different language of texts from 18th-19th centuries and different issue of the readings than other English texts that I usually read. I think the amount of texts made me quicker English-texts-reader.

I improved myself through Mr.Rasit's class in all three aspects mentioned above:
knowledge, skill, and insights.
First of all, I enhanced my understanding in certain social structure, and certain social phenomenon like the racial discrimination. I never thought about the authentic reason and explanation for some observations, only judging them as just or unjust in the past. Through this course, the theories developed by Marx, Weber, Durkheim, Du Bois, and other writers all broad my horizon in comprehending what is Sociology. 
Secondly, the skills I learnt on class cannot only be limited and narrowed down into essay writing skills, but also connecting history with modern social theories. Formal academic papers help me to improve my writing skills; class discussion assist me to improve my cognitive ability and critical thinking... All in all, it's a great course with a lot to learn from the knowledge per se, the instructor, and my classmates.
Finally, insights. After learning the course at YSS with Mr.Rasit, it seems that this term "Sociology" it's no longer distant for me. Viewing the world around me and explaining them with my own perspective could be a challenging task, but referencing through the lens of other sociologists will make this task easier and provide me diversified ways to analyze the society around me. It still requires effort to see how to use these things I learnt on class to plentiful fields and apply them to everyday lives.
The course could be improved by including projects or discussions that are more engaging and more suitable for students that are still in high school.

Being centered around a critique of western civilizations, which are assed by their colonial, imperial, and exploitative past, this course is of such
high value, because not only does it introduce the basic, most important works of sociology and more, but it nurtures discussion and, most important of all, it raises an informed student able to voice his*her concerns about inner contradictions in our current paradigm.

The only problem I see with this course is the time-frame. It is mentally not possible to absorb and really understand such vast amounts of material in such a short amount of time. Our professor, however, did a really good job of getting us all back together at the beginning of each session by analyzing, together with the class, and summarizing each and every text thoroughly.

Although I find the course really great and interesting, it was really hard to follow up with all readings for the next class in 2-4 days. I am not sure how you can improve that - maybe we should get advice to start reading it before the Summer Session started or the readings could be reduced a bit. And I think that it would be helpful to write especially mid-term assignment, if we have known the questions when reading the texts, because we could bold some parts of it which would be useful. I think also giving historical background by the teacher would be sometimes useful before reading the connected texts. I think the strongest part of the course is the teacher with his passion, great attitude, stubbornness in pursuit of true and not-only-American point of view. The teacher is really open. He broaden our knowledge, but also let us think by ourselves. I find great he form of seminar for the course.

I will list them again in a very simple and concrete form.
Strength: 
The great teaching methods and prodigious knowledge base of the professor
The uniqueness of the class contents per se (no course like this in high school)
The depth and width of the knowledge delivered from our professor through the texts of different authors
The thorough understanding delivered between students
The cultural diversity of students
etc.
Weakness:
I didn't come up with one yet. If I've got a chance, I would like to experience this whole thing again :)
